Avant- de vous revoir, j'étais résolue à tout vous dire, et quand je vous revis la confiance me manqua. Il n'y eut là-dedans ni raisonnement, ni calcul mais une force impérieuse et presque indépen-dante de ma volonté. Puis je me payais de défaites. Pourquoi troubler votre sécurité et éveiller vos soupçons? La chose en valait-elle la peine? Cet homme, en venant chez moi, avait obéi à un caprice probablement il n'y reviendrait plus. Et s'il revenait, quoi de plus aisé que de le remettre à sa place et de faire justice de ses airs cavaliers ? Était-il besoin d'aide pour cela et ne valait-il pas mieux procéder sans bruit, sans éclat, .comme une femme peut et doit le faire, que de mettre deux hommes en présence et jusqu'aux prises pour un si léger motif? Voilà à quelles impressions je cédai sans m'en rendre bien compte, ni pénétrer trop avant dans mon coeur Peut-être, hélas ! en interrogeant mieux ce coeur, aurais-je trouvé le dernier mot de ces réticences. La suite ne l'a que trop prouvé j'étais déjà touchée, j'entrais dans cette série de faiblesses qui m'ont perdue. C'est ici que j'ai besoin de votre pardon, Ludovic, d'un pardon absolu et généreux. Point d'excuse possible, rien qui puisse pallier ce commen-cement de trahison. Vous aviez été pour moi le meilleur, le plus dévoué et le plus fidèle des amis vous n'aviez qu'une pensée, mon bonheur qu'un but, notre union. Jamais, c'est une justice que je me plais à vous rendre, aucun chagrin ne m'est venu de vous si j'exprimais un désir, vous vous em-pressiez de le satisfaire si j'avais un ennui, vous vous offriez -à le partager. Vous étiez de ces loyaux compagnons qu'une femme est trop heureuse de rencontrer dans sa vie, qui l'as-sistent dans les bons et les mauvais jours et se donnent sans réserve comme sans calcul. Je voyais tout cela, je le sentais et ne méconnaissais point-vos mérites. Lui, au contraire, qu'était-il et quel fonds pouvais-je -

Pourquoi troubler votre sécurité et éveiller vos soupçons? La chose en valait-elle la peine? Cet homme, en venant chez moi, avait obéi à un caprice probablement il n'y reviendrait plus. Et s'il revenait, quoi de plus aisé que de le remettre à sa place et de faire justice de ses airs cavaliers ? Était-il besoin d'aide pour cela et ne valait-il pas mieux procéder sans bruit, sans éclat, .comme une femme peut et doit le faire, que de mettre deux hommes en présence et jusqu'aux prises pour un si léger motif? Voilà à quelles impressions je cédai sans m'en rendre bien compte, ni pénétrer trop avant dans mon coeur Peut-être, hélas ! en interrogeant mieux ce coeur, aurais-je trouvé le dernier mot de ces réticences. La suite ne l'a que trop prouvé j'étais déjà touchée, j'entrais dans cette série de faiblesses qui m'ont perdue. C'est ici que j'ai besoin de votre pardon, Ludovic, d'un pardon absolu et généreux. Point d'excuse possible, rien qui puisse pallier ce commen-cement de trahison. Vous aviez été pour moi le meilleur, le plus dévoué et le plus fidèle des amis vous n'aviez qu'une pensée, mon bonheur qu'un but, notre union. Vous étiez de ces loyaux compagnons qu'une femme est trop heureuse de rencontrer dans sa vie, qui l'as-sistent dans les bons et les mauvais jours et se donnent sans réserve comme sans calcul. Je voyais tout cela, je le sentais et ne méconnaissais point-vos mérites. Lui, au contraire, qu'était-il et quel fonds pouvais-je -

groundtruth.region: CE PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 257 j'obéis, tant il y avait en moi de confusion et de trouble. Il faut si peu de chose pour arrêter une confidence sur les lèvres, surtout lorsqu'il s'agit de s'accuser d'un tort et de se mettre à la merci d'autrui ! On s'empare alors du premier prétexte, le plus futile, le plus spécieux on recule, on ajourne, et, dans ces ajournements mêmes, on puise des mo-tifs pour s'abstenir. C'est ce qui m'arriva, Ludovic. Avant de vous revoir, j'étais résolue à tout vous dire, et quand je vous revis la confiance me manqua. Il n'y eut là-dedans ni raisonnement, ni calcul mais une force impérieuse et presque indépen-dante de ma volonté. Puis je me payais de défaites. Pourquoi troubler votre sécurité et éveiller vos soupçons ? La chose en valait-elle la peine ? Cet homme, en venant chez moi, avait obéi à un caprice probablement il n'y reviendrait plus. Et s'il revenait, quoi de plus aisé que de le remettre à sa place et de faire justice de ses airs cavaliers ? Était-il besoin d'aide pour cela et ne valait-il pas mieux procéder sans bruit, sans éclat, comme une femme peut et doit le faire, que de mettre deux hommes en présence et jusqu'aux prises pour un si léger motif ? Voilà à quelles impressions je cédai sans m'en rendre bien compte, ni pénétrer trop avant dans mon coeur Peut-être, hélas ! en interrogeant mieux ce coeur, aurais-je trouvé le dernier mot de ces réticences. La suite ne l'a que trop prouvé j'étais déjà touchée, j'entrais dans cette série de faiblesses qui m'ont perdue. C'est ici que j'ai besoin de votre pardon, Ludovic, d'un pardon absolu et généreux. Point d'excuse possible, rien qui puisse pallier ce commen-cement de trahison. Vous aviez été pour moi le meilleur, le plus dévoué et le plus fidèle des amis vous n'aviez qu'une pensée, mon bonheur qu'un but, notre union. Jamais, c'est une justice que je me plais à vous rendre, aucun chagrin ne m'est venu de vous si j'exprimais un désir, vous vous em-pressiez de le satisfaire si j'avais un ennui, vous vous offriez à le partager. Vous étiez de ces loyaux compagnons qu'une femme est trop heureuse de rencontrer dans sa vie, qui l'as-sistent dans les bons et les mauvais jours et se donnent sans réserve comme sans calcul. Je voyais tout cela, je le sentais et ne méconnaissais point vos mérites. Lui, au contraire, qu'était-il et quel fonds

ocr.sentence: LES TÉLÉPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 11 -Dans deux heures.
ocr.region: LES TÉLÉPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 11 - Dans deux heures. Où est notre poste? • 'j,' '.tJit,d - J'en sais rien. - ~ H - Merci! Et sans se rebuter il continua, s'adressant à des poilus qui tiraillaient quelques cartouches. - C'est les téléphonistes. - Ah, les embusqués! chuchotèrent les hommes. - Oui, embusqués de première ligne comme vous autres, répondit Régnier rageusement, et il continua à questionner - Le poste téléphonique? - Taisez-vous, souffla un sergent, nous sommes à vingt mètres des Boches! Soudain une tête surgit d'un trou et un bras lui lit signe d'approcher. - C'est nous, fit Régnier, où est le poste? - Y en a pas, répondit une voix, on est tassés dans un gourbi! Couché presque à plat ventre, Régnier se raunJa dans l'exca-vation. - C'est maigre, miladious! murmura-t-il, enQn.! Accroupi, ramassé sur lui-même, 11 établit tant bien que mal sa communication. - Allo! caporal Legrand, c'est vous?. C'est Régnier qui est à l'appareil. Bon. ça marche. Vous dites?. Ah! oui, je crois que le climat n'est pas sain, vu l'humidité. J'ai peur de prendre racine. Je me sens déjà des fourmis dans les jambes. Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal. - Dites donc, vous n'êtes pas là pour faire la causette, fit brusquement un adjudant, fermez ça une fois pour toutes. Le mieux pour lui était de ne pas répliquer, car il se sentait dans une atmosphère hostile. Les deux soldats qui partaient, sans plus tarder, mirent leuss sacs, s'éloignèrent sur une poignée de main. - Ce n'est pas confortable là dedans, soupira le Méridional assis en tailleur. j'ai des crampes dans tes genoux, mais ce qui me console, c'est que je ne paie pas mon loyer! La nuit s'annonçait assez tranquille, fatigués par les atta. ques des jours précédents, les Allemands paraissaient plutôt inquiets qu'agressifs. Insensible et brisé de fatigue. Buchard s'était endormi. Seul Régnier veillait et comme il n'avait personne à qui parler, 11 s'élait mis à manger un morceau de singe et vidait ce qui lql restait de pinard.

Et sans se rebuter il continua, s'adressant à des poilus qui tiraillaient quelques cartouches. - C'est les téléphonistes. - Ah, les embusqués! chuchotèrent les hommes. - Oui, embusqués de première ligne comme vous autres, répondit Régnier rageusement, et il continua à questionner - Le poste téléphonique? - Taisez-vous, souffla un sergent, nous sommes à vingt mètres des Boches! Soudain une tête surgit d'un trou et un bras lui lit signe d'approcher. - C'est nous, fit Régnier, où est le poste? - Y en a pas, répondit une voix, on est tassés dans un gourbi! Couché presque à plat ventre, Régnier se raunJa dans l'exca-vation. - C'est maigre, miladious! murmura-t-il, enQn.! Accroupi, ramassé sur lui-même, 11 établit tant bien que mal sa communication. - Allo! caporal Legrand, c'est vous?. C'est Régnier qui est à l'appareil. Bon. ça marche. Vous dites?. Ah! oui, je crois que le climat n'est pas sain, vu l'humidité. J'ai peur de prendre racine. Je me sens déjà des fourmis dans les jambes. Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal. - Dites donc, vous n'êtes pas là pour faire la causette, fit brusquement un adjudant, fermez ça une fois pour toutes. Le mieux pour lui était de ne pas répliquer, car il se sentait dans une atmosphère hostile. Les deux soldats qui partaient, sans plus tarder, mirent leuss sacs, s'éloignèrent sur une poignée de main. - Ce n'est pas confortable là dedans, soupira le Méridional assis en tailleur. j'ai des crampes dans tes genoux, mais ce qui me console, c'est que je ne paie pas mon loyer! La nuit s'annonçait assez tranquille, fatigués par les atta. ques des jours précédents, les Allemands paraissaient plutôt inquiets qu'agressifs. Insensible et brisé de fatigue. Buchard s'était endormi. Seul Régnier veillait et comme il n'avait personne à qui parler, 11 s'élait mis à manger un morceau de singe et vidait ce qui lql restait de pinard.

Couché presque à plat ventre, Régnier se faufila dans l'exca-vation. -C'est maigre, miladious! murmura-t-il, enfin...! Accroupi, ramassé sur lui-même, il établit tant bien que mal sa communication. -Allo! caporal Legrand, c'est vous?... C'est Régnier qui est à l'appareil... Bon... ça marche... Vous dites?... Ah! oui, je crois que le climat n'est pas sain, vu l'humidité. J'ai peur de prendre racine. Je me sens déjà des fourmis dans les jambes... Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal. -Dites donc, vous n'êtes pas là pour faire la causette, fit brusquement un adjudant, fermez ça une fois pour toutes. Le mieux pour lui était de ne pas répliquer, car il se sentait dans une atmosphère hostile. Les deux soldats qui partaient, sans plus tarder, mirent leurs sacs, s'éloignèrent sur une poignée de main. -Ce n'est pas confortable là dedans, soupira le Méridional assis en tailleur, j'ai des crampes dans les genoux, mais ce qui me console, c'est que je ne paie pas mon loyer! La nuit s'annonçait assez tranquille, fatigués par les atta-ques des jours précédents, les Allemands paraissaient plutôt inquiets qu'agressifs. Insensible et brisé de fatigue. Buchard s'était endormi. Seul Régnier veillait et comme il n'avait personne à qui parler, il s'était mis à manger un morceau de singe et vidait ce qui lui restait de pinard.

ocr.sentence: 14 L'ANE GRIS En ce moment, et, comme si elle eût répondu à son appel, la cloche de la maison paternelle retentit dans les airs.
ocr.region: 14 L'ANE GRIS En ce moment, et, comme si elle eût répondu à son appel, la cloche de la maison paternelle retentit dans les airs. Était-ce bien possible, est-ce qu'il ne serait encore que l'heure du coucher?. Sans s'en douter, Édouard avait fait le tour du parc au lieu d'aller tout droit par l'allée du milieu, il avait tourné sur lui-même et était revenu à son point de départ. C'était bien là la porte du jardin. Il n'était que neuf heures. La cloche continuait à sonner. Sans doute on s'était aperçu de son absence. Ce second coup de -cloche était pour l'appeler. Encore un effort et ses ennemis vont s'arrêter, bien sûr il n'oseront pas le poursuivre si près de la maison. En tout cas, il y arrivera le premier ! Le petit Edouard se trompait. La poursuite continuait. Mais Édouard était rentré dans le jardin. Toute sa famille était là qui l'appelait, qui le cherchait. Son père était sur la plate-forme du perron. Les domestiques effarés couraient partout avec des lanternes. Chacun criait Édouard, Édouard! La voix de sa soeur venait jusqu'à lui. Papa ! papa ! s'écria Édouard, cher papa ! je suis là ! Et le petit Édouard tombait à moitié mort de peur dans les bras de son père. Mais il n'arrivait pas seul. Les voleurs, les gendarmes, tous ses ennemis, tous ses persécuteurs, animés sans doute, eux aussi, par leur course, avaient franchi la porte du jardin et faisaient effrontément irruption dans le salon en sonnant une fanfare éclatante. Le croirait-on? mais la vérité nous oblige à le confesser la troupe des fantômes devant laquelle avait fui l'intrépide Édouard se composait d'un seul malfaiteur!. son petit âne, qui, en se trouvant tout à coup au milieu des lumières du salon, avait cru devoir célébrer son entrée par le plus beau braiement qui fût jamais sorti de son gosier.

Sans s'en douter, Édouard avait fait le tour du parc au lieu d'aller tout droit par l'allée du milieu, il avait tourné sur lui-même et était revenu à son point de départ. C'était bien là la porte du jardin. Il n'était que neuf heures. La cloche continuait à sonner. Sans doute on s'était aperçu de son absence. Ce second coup de -cloche était pour l'appeler. Encore un effort et ses ennemis vont s'arrêter, bien sûr il n'oseront pas le poursuivre si près de la maison. En tout cas, il y arrivera le premier ! Le petit Edouard se trompait. La poursuite continuait. Mais Édouard était rentré dans le jardin. Toute sa famille était là qui l'appelait, qui le cherchait. Son père était sur la plate-forme du perron. Les domestiques effarés couraient partout avec des lanternes. Chacun criait Édouard, Édouard! La voix de sa soeur venait jusqu'à lui. Papa ! papa ! s'écria Édouard, cher papa ! je suis là ! Et le petit Édouard tombait à moitié mort de peur dans les bras de son père. Mais il n'arrivait pas seul. Les voleurs, les gendarmes, tous ses ennemis, tous ses persécuteurs, animés sans doute, eux aussi, par leur course, avaient franchi la porte du jardin et faisaient effrontément irruption dans le salon en sonnant une fanfare éclatante. Le croirait-on? mais la vérité nous oblige à le confesser la troupe des fantômes devant laquelle avait fui l'intrépide Édouard se composait d'un seul malfaiteur!. son petit âne, qui, en se trouvant tout à coup au milieu des lumières du salon, avait cru devoir célébrer son entrée par le plus beau braiement qui fût jamais sorti de son gosier.
groundtruth.sentence: C'était bien là la porte du jardin.

Sans s'en douter, Édouard avait fait le tour du parc au lieu d'aller tout droit par l'allée du milieu, il avait tourné sur lui-même et était revenu à son point de départ. C'était bien là la porte du jardin. Il n'était que neuf heures. La cloche continuait à sonner. Sans doute on s'était aperçu de son absence. Ce second coup de -cloche était pour l'appeler. Encore un effort et ses ennemis vont s'arrêter, bien sûr il n'oseront pas le poursuivre si près de la maison. En tout cas, il y arrivera le premier ! Le petit Edouard se trompait. La poursuite continuait. Mais Édouard était rentré dans le jardin. Toute sa famille était là qui l'appelait, qui le cherchait. Son père était sur la plate-forme du perron. Les domestiques effarés couraient partout avec des lanternes. Chacun criait Édouard, Édouard! La voix de sa soeur venait jusqu'à lui. Papa ! papa ! s'écria Édouard, cher papa ! je suis là ! Et le petit Édouard tombait à moitié mort de peur dans les bras de son père. Mais il n'arrivait pas seul. Les voleurs, les gendarmes, tous ses ennemis, tous ses persécuteurs, animés sans doute, eux aussi, par leur course, avaient franchi la porte du jardin et faisaient effrontément irruption dans le salon en sonnant une fanfare éclatante. Le croirait-on? mais la vérité nous oblige à le confesser la troupe des fantômes devant laquelle avait fui l'intrépide Édouard se composait d'un seul malfaiteur!. son petit âne, qui, en se trouvant tout à coup au milieu des lumières du salon, avait cru devoir célébrer son entrée par le plus beau braiement qui fût jamais sorti de son gosier.
groundtruth.sentence: Son père était sur la plate-forme du perron.

Encore un effort et ses ennemis vont s'arrêter, bien sûr il n'oseront pas le poursuivre si près de la maison. En tout cas, il y arrivera le premier! Le petit Édouard se trompait. La poursuite continuait. Mais Édouard était rentré dans le jardin. Toute sa famille était là qui l'appelait, qui le cherchait. Son père était sur la plate-forme du perron. Les domestiques effarés couraient partout avec des lanternes. Chacun criait Édouard, Édouard ! La voix de sa soeur venait jusqu'à lui. Papa ! papa ! s'écria Édouard, cher papa! je suis là ! Et le petit Édouard tombait à moitié mort de peur dans les bras de son père. Mais il n'arrivait pas seul. Les voleurs, les gendarmes, tous ses ennemis, tous ses persécuteurs, animés sans doute, eux aussi, par leur course, avaient franchi la porte du jardin et faisaient effrontément irruption dans le salon en sonnant une fanfare éclatante. Le croirait-on? mais la vérité nous oblige à le confesser la troupe des fantômes devant laquelle avait fui l'intrépide Édouard se composait d'un seul malfaiteur!... son petit âne, qui, en se trouvant tout à coup au milieu des lumières du salon, avait cru devoir célébrer son entrée par le plus beau braiement qui fût jamais sorti de son gosier.

Le croirait-on? mais la vérité nous oblige à le confesser la troupe des fantômes devant laquelle avait fui l'intrépide Édouard se composait d'un seul malfaiteur!... son petit âne, qui, en se trouvant tout à coup au milieu des lumières du salon, avait cru devoir célébrer son entrée par le plus beau braiement qui fût jamais sorti de son gosier.

ocr.sentence: have gone their wayes.
ocr.region: OF FRYER BACON. 223 would have gone their wayes. Nay, said Fryer Bacon, I pray gentlemen at my request tarry a little, and heare some of my mans musicke you are byred reasonable wed already, I hope in courtesie you will not deny mee so small a request. That wiU wee not, said they all. Mdes thought now to have some sport with them, which hee bad, and therefore plaid lustily on his tabor and pipe so soone as they heard him play against their wdls they fell a dauncing, and that after such a laborious manner, that they quickly wearied themselves for they had aH that while the bagges of money in their hands. Tet had Fryer Bacon not revenge enough of them, but bid his man Mdes leave them some larger measure as hee thought fitting, which Miles did. Mdes straight ledde them out of the house into the fields, they foUowed him, dauncing after a wilde anticke man ner then led hee them over a broad dike fidl of water and they foUowed him still, but not so good a way as he went for he went over the bridge, but they by reason of their dauncing, could not keepe the bridge, but fell off, and dauncing through the water then led bee them through a way where a horse might very well have been up to the beUy they foUowed him, and were so durtie, a s though they had wallowed in the myre hke swine sometime gave hee them rest onely to laugh at them then were they so sleepie when hee did not play, that they feU to the ground. Then on a sudden would hee play againe, and make them start up and follow him. Thus kept hee them the better part of the night. At

ocr.region: 277 OF FRIER RUSH. then he said to Rush, thou lew d fellow, what bast thou done to this waggon that I am thus arayed therein ? Rush answered and said sir, I have done nothing but as you commanded me. That is not, said the Priour, for I commaunded thee to take greace and grease but the wheeles and the axeltrees, and thou hast taken tarre and annointed it all over, both within and without. Why hast thou done so ? Sir said Rush, I understoode you bad me doe so. And when the Priour sawe there was no other remedie, he commanded his servants to makeready another waggon, and in the meane season, the Priour went into his chamber, and put on another babite, and came againe and mounted into the waggon and went their way, and so long they rode, that they came to their iourneyes end. And when they were alighted at their lodging, the Priour caUed for his supper, and anon every thing was made ready, and the good man of the house and the Priour sate downe to supper together, and made good cheere and then the Priour called for wine of the best, and anon he had his commandement. And when the good man of the house and the Priour had supped, Rush and bis fellowes sate downe to the rever sions that their maisters bad left, but they had no wine wherefore Rush was very sad, and ever he mused by what policie he might get some wine. And when the Priour sawe there was no other remedie, he commanded his servants to makeready another waggon, and in the meane season, the Priour went into his chamber, and put on another babite, and came againe and mounted into the waggon and went their way, and so long they rode, that they came to their iourneyes end. And when they were alighted at their lodging, the Priour caUed for his supper, and anon every thing was made ready, and the good man of the house and the Priour sate downe to supper together, and made good cheere and then the Priour called for wine of the best, and anon he had his commandement. And when the good man of the house and the Priour had supped, Rush and bis fellowes sate downe to the rever sions that their maisters bad left, but they had no wine wherefore Rush was very sad, and ever he mused by what policie he might get some wine. And anon he called the wife of the house and said Mistresse, I pray you fill a pottle of wine for me and my fellowes, and so shee did and when that was gone, they caUed for another and then they called for the third, and so ended their

ocr.region: 274 A PLEASANT HISTORIE had been there should have seene good buffets given on both parties. And when Frier Rush saw that they were fighting together, anon he blew out all the candles and lamps that were burning in the church, and left no manner of Hght therein whereby the one might see the other and when he had so done, be tooke his truncheon in his hand, and went into the Quier among the thickest of the Friers the which were fighting freshly without light, and there he laid so lustily about, that many of them he felled to the ground, and left them there for dead, and when he had so done, he stole his way from them, and as hee went, he found standing in the portaU of the Quier, a great olde deske, and anon hee tooke the deske betweene both his hands, and threw it over the portad into the Quier among aU the Friers, and hurt many sore, in so much that some had an arme broken, and some a legge, and other some had their noses, cleane pared from their faces, that the bloud ranne in their mouthes, and as for broken heads to the hard scalpe were no dainty, for every man had one, there scaped none free away, who had been there, should have had a goodly pastime to see the Friers creepe about the Quier, and in steede of Domine labia they cried out alas and well away. Then when the fray was done, and all the noyse seased, Rush came in among them with a candell light in his hand, and made as he had knowne nothing thereof, and said to them Fie for shame sirs, how fortuned this discord to faU among your selves ? I see well now you regard not your honour, nor the good

And when Frier Rush saw that they were fighting together, anon he blew out all the candles and lamps that were burning in the church, and left no manner of fight therein whereby the one might see the other and when he had so done, he tooke his truncheon in his hand, and went into the Quier among the thickest of the Friers the which were fighting freshly without light, and there he laid so lustily about, that many of them he felled to the ground, and left them there for dead, and when he had so done, he stole his way from them, and as hee went, he found standing in the portall of the Quier, a great olde deske, and anon hee tooke the deske betweene both his hands, and threw it over the portall into the Quier among all the Friers, and hurt many sore, in so much that some had an arme broken, and some a legge, and other some had their noses, cleane pared from their faces, that the bloud ranne in their mouthes, and as for broken heads to the hard scalpe were no dainty, for every man had one, there scaped none free away, who had been there, should have had a goodly pastime to see the Friers creepe about the Quier, and in steede of Domine labia they cried out alas and well away. Then when the fray was done, and all the noyse seased, Rush came in among them with a candell light in his hand, and made as he had knowne nothing thereof, and said to them Fie for shame sirs, how fortuned this discord to fall among your selves ? I see well now you regard not your honour, nor the good

275 When the Friers were in battle with each other, and as a man made so much noise as to be heard, I heard a shout of the Frieses. Some were standing about in the plaza, but not many of them were there, and as soon as the Frieses had seen me they ran in at me. I was so near that all the men that were present fell to the ground, but the Frieses not one, that they had a goodly way to their own bodies. Some fell on their hands, and some fell on the knees, but none on their feet. I saw them, and they looked as if they were very fit, and I asked who they were, but none told me. Then Rush took his truncheon in his hand, and made as he had knowne nothing of the Frieses that were near, he was with the men that was fighting with his own hand, he was going into the plaza with the fray, and having made as much noise as to be heard, fell to the ground. And when he had done he stole out of the plaza and left them there for dead. When the fray was done, and all the noyse seased, I said to the Frieses to make a fight or fight with their own hand. And they said to me, you can do it, for it is well and good, for we are here with you, and in that place is the place where we fought together. They were a goodly men, and I am as great an enemy as any. The Frieses ran into the plaza in great numbers, and after I had made them do it, they ran in into the place where I fought, and as they ran in and left them there for dead, they ran out of the plaza to make another fight, and as soon as they had done it, they ran out of the plaza to make another fight. I told the Frieses to fight with their own hand, and they did it, and when they were done, they ran out of the plaza to make another fight, and when they had done it, they ran back into the plaza and left them there for dead.

Another time it fortuned that the Priour had a journey to ride into the country about a Httle businesse that hee had there to doe, and anon he caUed Rush his servant unto him and said, Rush goe thy way into the court, and take with thee a dish fuU ofgreace. and greace weU the wheeles and axeltrees of the waggon, and make aU things ready against to-morrow in the morning, for I must ride forth to-morrow betimes, then Rush departed from his maister, and went about bis businesse, and insteed of greace, hee tooke a great vesseU full of tarre, and anointed the w-aggon all over with it, both within and without, and especiaUy in the place where the Priour should sit and when he had done, he returned to his maister's chamber, then the Priour demanded of Rush, if he had done as he commanded him yea sir said Rush, ye may ride when please you, aud so they weut to their beds. Then on the morrow after, the Priour and Rush his servant with his other company, rose up very early in the morning for to accomplish their journey, and forth they went unto their waggon, and when the Priour was entred therein, hee perceived himselfe all to betrayed and smeyred, and all his clothes were filed therewith and

276 A POEM FROULD be but such, if not so sweet, if not so sweet as the words in which it is said.
Frier Rush, therefore, brought forth the waggon of a journey, which he had already begun.
Hee, that hath made a journey to his maister, and to his servant and their father and mother, to his son and sonne, and so he made the journey.
But now, that he be sent forth to journey, I tell ye, as it happened, hee went forth to the country, and there they found him and hee both fell into the pit of the fire.
The Priour heard them and hee both fell and groaned, and hee groaned so loud that hee fell into the pit, and the other men also fell, and they both fell and groaned, and they both groaned and fell. When the Priour heard them, hee returned to his maister's chamber and to the Priour's servant and said, Why did you go into this country? And he answered, because I went with a waggon to journey, and now hee hath taken a great vesseU full of tarre, and made them to eat and drink of it, and I tell ye that if you doe not, it will be thy first death.

Hee went forth again to the country, and there he saw him and he fell in the pit of the fire and groaned, he fell in the pit and groaned and cried, and he fell in the pit, and groaned and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned, and groaned.

And I brought him a dish of greace of tarre, and made him drink of it, and I gave him a dish of tarre, which he had brought from the country, and he took with him the dish of tarre, which he had brought from the country, and hee brought him unto his maister's chamber.

The young Priour made haste with his people that day and set sail to go upon that same route.

THE EFFECT:

This sentence contains the intention to show that it is preferable to use a negative ending rather than a positive ending. Therefore, in this sentence, the sentence to correct has the positive ending and the sentence to remedy has the negative ending.

CORRECTED TEXTS:
It is the purpose of the present discourse to show that the choice of the negative ending is appropriate and also the choice of the positive ending is appropriate. The positive ending was not appropriate because it was not correct;
the negative ending was appropriate because it was correct; and the positive ending was correct because it was not correct.

ocr.sentence: their malicious mindes and angry hearts, every man after other went privately to Frier Rush to lend them staves, in so much that there was not a Frier in the place but he had one, and they never went without their staves under their habite, and the one knew not that the other had any, they kept them so secretly.
ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 273 filling their malicious mindes and angry hearts, every man after other went privately to Frier Rush to lend them staves, in so much that there was not a Frier in the place but he had one, and they never went without their staves under their habite, and the one knew not that the other had any, they kept them so secretly. And when Frier Rush had delivered aH his staves, he was right glad in his heart, for he knew right well there should be a great fray among them, either one time or other. So it fortuned afterward, as it is a common cus-tome among religious people at an high feast, to keepe solemne service, and every man to be at Mattens at midnight, and so upon a good night, all the whole Covent assembled together in the Quier, and were ready to begin Mattens, they taried for nothing but for the comming of the Priour. Then anon the Priour came into the Quier, and sate him downe in his place, and as he looked about him, he espied that the Subpriour was there present, and with that his heart began to grudge of the olde anger that was fallen betweene them two, and he thought in his minde that he could never be revenged in a better time, and sodainly he rose out of his place, and went to the Subpriour, and with his fist he gave him a good buffet, and the Subpriour which was moved with the stroke, started unto the Priour and gave him another buffet, and with that they went freshly together by the eares, and when the other Friers saw that, every man rose out of their places, and drew out their Truncheons, and together they went who VOL. I.

So they came to their Father, and the two of them who came at the front stood on the side of the altar to make prayer, and at the same time he commanded the others to make prayer, as they were ready.


THE QUERY:
Who is the first to enter the Covent for a time in the evening (for there is not a person in the Covent but a priest, and the first to enter it at midnight is the Priest).


THE QUESTION:
What was the reason for the priests making the prayer?

THE RABBIT:
Well, the Lord commanded us to do so, because they were so fast, and our bodies had not grown up, and therefore they were ready.


THE RABBIT:
Well, and why did they call themselves the first to enter the Covent?


THE RABBIT:
Well

Then the Priour went into the Hall, and stood in the midst of the fray,
and at that time the other Friers came up to him, and told him they had seen
the Priour with a knife, and asked him why he could be revenged in his
mighty hand, and he answered that he knew how to be revenged. He therefore
took his knife, and gave him a drink to that, and said unto the other
Friers, and saying, This may be what the Lord hath to do with thee;
for there is not that in the world that hath been revenged, but this I am
to do with thee; for this is the work of thy hand, and in thy hands
there are not that that are revenged. After that they came together,
and the Priour and the other Friers had the liquor to themselves.
After that the Priour rose out of the place, and went towards his
friends, and saying unto them, I am going into the Hall, and will
have them there to see me. And the other Friers that were with the
priour, said unto him, Be not fearfull, for this will be the work of
thy hand, and I have not thyself but to come in to you, and to offer

ocr.sentence: who fought with the dragon, and killed it Vandermast following his example raysed up Perseus, who fought also with his sea-monster, and killed it, so were they both released from their danger.
ocr.region: OF FRYER BACON. 243 George, who fought with the dragon, and killed it Vandermast following his example raysed up Perseus, who fought also with his sea-monster, and kdled it, so were they both released from their danger. They being not contented with this tryall of their skill, went further in their coniurations, and raised up two spirits, each of them one. Bungye charged his spirit for to assist him with the greatest power hee had, that by it he might be able to overcome Vandermast. The Devdl told him he would, if that he from his left arme would give him but three drops of blood but if that he did deny him that, then should Vandermast have power over him to doe what he would the Hke told Vandermasts Devill to him to this demand of the spirits, they both agreed, thinking for to overcome each other but the Devill overthrew them both. They having given the Devill this bloud, as is before spoken of, they both fell againe to their coniurations first, Bungye did rayse Achilles with bis Greekes, who marched about Vandermast and threatned him. Then Vandermast raised Hector with his Troians, who defended him from AchiUes and the Greekes. Then began there a great batteU between the Greekes and Troians, which continued a good space at last Hector was slaine, and the Troians fled. Then did follow a great tempest, with thundring and lightning, so that the two coniurers wished that they had been away. But wishes were in vaine for now the time was come, that the Devill would be paid for the knowledge that he had

prediction.region:
The dragon, who fought with his sea-monster, and killed it, Vandermast following his example raysed up Perseus, who fought with his sea-monster, and kdled it, so were they both released from their danger. They being not contented with this tryall of their skill, went further in their coniurations, and raised up two spirits, each of them one. Bungye charged his spirit for to assist him with the greatest power hee had, that by it he might be able to overcome Vandermast. The Devdl told him he would, if that he from his left arme would give him but three drops of blood but if that he did deny him that, then should Vandermast have power over him to doe what he would the Hke told Vandermasts Devill to him to this demand of the spirits, they both agreed, thinking for to overcome each other but the Devill overthrew them both. They having given the Devill this bloud, as is before spoken of, they both fell againe to their coniurations first, Bungye did rayse Achilles with bis Greekes, who marched about Vandermast and threatned him. Then Vandermast raised Hector with his Troians, who defended him from AchiUes and the Greekes. Then began there a great batteU between the Greekes and Troians, which continued a good space at last Hector was slaine, and the Troians fled. Then did follow a great tempest, with thundring and lightning, so that the two coniurers wished that they had been away. But wishes were in vaine for now the time was come, that the Devill would be paid for the knowledge that he had

ocr.region: 264 A PLEASANT HISTORIE good and well disposed people, they spent in unthrifti nesse and rybauldry. And when the great prince of devils which are the patrones of aU vices understood of the great misrule and rile living of these religious men consulted to keepe them still in that state, and worse if it might be. And these be the names of the devils. Belphegor who was Prince of Gluttony, Asmodeus Prince of Lechery, and Belzebub Prince of Envie, with many other divels assembled together, which reioyced for the misorder of these religious men. And as they were all assembled together with one accord they chose a divell to goe and dwell among these religious men, for to maintaine them the longer in their ungracious living, which divell was put in rayment Hke an earthly crea ture, and went to a religious house, and there he stood at the gate a certaine space all alone with an heavie countenance. Then within a while after the Priour came unto the gate and espied Rush the young man standing there ad alone. Anon he said unto him, what dost thou here, and what wouldest thou have. The young man with great reverence answered and said Sir, I am a poore young man, and am out of service, and faine would have a maister. And sir if it please you to have me, I shall doe you diligent service, and shaddoe so well that you and all your brethren and covent shall be glad of me, for I shall keepe so weU your secrets, that I trust to obtaine at all times your good love and favour, and all theirs also. And when the Priour had heard his words, he was

prediction.region: 266 A FAMOUS GAME, that he said, who are they? So the Priour said unto the young man, and said I, is this that I saw that day in the forest, that hath ye not seen yet? And the young man answer, ye must see. And the Priour said, ye must see. So the young man said, and said he, I see him, a large man, and the bane of the beater, as well as a great man, and a wise man, and an honest man, and a king, and a great king, and a wise king, and a king; and I saw them, and ye know it, and ye see them and they doe them service. And the young man said, and said he, ye cannot say so. And the Priour answered and said to the young man, what dost thou now doe? The young man said, I am a very poor man, I have no more service, and for my sake he will keep me still. And the Priour said to him, what dost thou doe? The young man said, I doe not doe it any other way, for it will be that for I should not stay at a place untruly fit for me. And the Priour said to him, is this that is thy name, thy father? The young man said, ye cannot say so. And the Priour answered and said to him, what dost thou doe? The young man said, I doe not doe it any other way, for it will be that for I shall not stay at a place untruly fit for me. And the Priour said to him, is this that is thy father, thy grandfather, thy great grandfather, thy great grandfather, thy great grandfather? The young man said, ye cannot say so. And the Priour answered and said to him, what dost thou doe? The young man said, I doe not doe it any other way, for it will be that for I shall not stay at a place untruly fit for me. And the Priour said to him, is this that is thy father, thy great grandfather, thy great grandfather, thy great grandfather? The young man said, ye cannot say so.
